title: Delta1 Lyrae
text:
Delta1 Lyrae, its name <a href="Latinisation%20of%20names">Latinized</a> from δ1 Lyrae, is a <a href="binary%20star">binary star</a> system in the northern <a href="constellation">constellation</a> of <a href="Lyra%20%28constellation%29">Lyra</a>. It is dimly visible to the naked eye at night with a combined <a href="apparent%20visual%20magnitude">apparent visual magnitude</a> of 5.56. The system is located at a distance of approximately 1,160 <a href="light%20year">light year</a>s from the <a href="Sun">Sun</a> based on <a href="stellar%20parallax">parallax</a>, but is drifting closer with a <a href="radial%20velocity">radial velocity</a> of −26 km/s. <a href="Olin%20J.%20Eggen">O. J. Eggen</a> originally included this as a candidate member of the proposed <a href="Delta%20Lyrae%20cluster">Delta Lyrae cluster</a>.
The variable <a href="radial%20velocity">radial velocity</a> of this star was discovered from photographic plates taken at the <a href="Yerkes%20Observatory">Yerkes Observatory</a> in 1904. The first set of <a href="orbital%20elements">orbital elements</a> was computed by Frank Craig Jordan in 1916. It is a single-lined <a href="spectroscopic%20binary">spectroscopic binary</a> with an <a href="orbital%20period">orbital period</a> of 88.4 days and an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> (ovalness) of 0.37.
The visible component of the pair has a blue-white hue with a <a href="stellar%20classification">stellar classification</a> of B2.5V, indicating that it is a <a href="B-type%20main-sequence%20star">B-type main-sequence star</a> undergoing <a href="stellar%20core">core</a> <a href="hydrogen%20fusion">hydrogen fusion</a>. It is a few million years old with a relatively high rotation rate and around 7–8 times the mass of the Sun. The star is radiating about 3,620 times the Sun's luminosity from its <a href="photosphere">photosphere</a> at an <a href="effective%20temperature">effective temperature</a> of 20,350 K.
There is a magnitude 9.93 visual companion at an <a href="angular%20separation">angular separation</a> of along a <a href="position%20angle">position angle</a> of 20°, as of 2012. This component was discovered by William Herschel. It is an <a href="stellar%20evolution">evolved</a> <a href="giant%20star">giant star</a> with a class of K2III at a distance of around 1,760 light years.
